evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_baseline_t1_early timeframe.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence contradicting the occurrence of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early context, supporting its validity as a root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early data, such as timing and crew interactions.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_baseline_t1_early timeframe.

assumptions: Communication between tug instructor, trainee, and headset operator reflects crew coordination.
Passing the TRP and hitting the barrier indicates a breakdown in communication/coordination.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the aircraft from passing the TRP or hitting the barrier, or if procedural deviation better explained the event.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows communication between crew and headset operator, seat swap and pushback continuation, but aircraft passed TRP and hit barrier, indicating coordination issues supporting communication breakdown claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the event was primarily a procedural deviation or communication breakdown

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early data, such as timing and crew interactions.

assumptions: Crew interactions described reflect communication/coordination quality relevant to the claim.
No unreported mechanical or environmental factors influenced the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviations without communication issues, or hardware faults causing the event, the conclusion would change.
If environment or marking deficiencies were documented as primary causes, the attribution to communication breakdown would weaken.

No mechanical control failure evidence is present to explain the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and intact and the crew failed to comply, this would favor procedural deviation instead.
If communication logs indicated crew coordination failures leading to the event, this would favor communication breakdown.
If mechanical fault codes or malfunctions were verified, this would favor mechanical control failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP ground markings and hit a barrier, indicating environmental markings were not maintained to ensure availability during operations, thus contradicting the claim. Discriminators favor environmental marking deficiency over procedural deviation or communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the markings were physically deficient or crew failed to comply; no direct statement on marking condition

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were not physically present or inaccessible during the operation, or communication was absent.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 directly indicate crew members were physically present and accessible during the operation, supporting the claim.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, cockpit voice recordings, and witness statements to confirm presence and accessibility

children_spec.statement: Communication equipment was operational and available to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance records and equipment status reports; analyze cockpit voice recorder for communication signals

children_spec.statement: Crew attempted to communicate but failed to coordinate effectively
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze cockpit voice recordings and crew interviews to identify attempts and failures in communication

children_spec.statement: The environmental conditions at the time match known conditions that cause the deficiency
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare recorded environmental data (weather, lighting, temperature) with conditions known to cause the deficiency; evidence that conditions differ significantly lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Marking or signage deficiencies correspond exactly to the key features identified in the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the physical markings and signage for presence, visibility, and correctness; evidence of correct and adequate markings lowers probability

children_spec.statement: The deficiency aligns with documented historical baseline data for similar conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Review historical baseline data for similar environmental or marking conditions; absence of similar deficiencies in baseline data lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft's mechanical control components for presence and physical integrity; absence or damage would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from obstructions or blockages
children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any physical obstructions or blockages in the mechanical control pathways; detection of obstructions would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control inputs and control surfaces; disconnections or misalignments would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components operate without excessive wear or damage that impairs function
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess mechanical components for wear, corrosion, or damage that could impair operation; evidence of such would lower availability

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were absent or inaccessible during the incident, or communication was impossible.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 directly indicate that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and accessible during the incident, supporting the claim.
